image.altText: Daniel Andrews announces Commonwealth Games cancellation

items.synopsis: Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews confirms the state will no longer host the 2026 Commonwealth Games due to cost blowouts. Follow live.

title.children: 'Disappointing is an understatement': Regions react as Victoria ditches Commonwealth Games

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese was a little hesitant to say too much about the Games cancellation, preferring to focus on events that were actually going ahead. "That's a decision made by the Victorian government. I'll leave the Victorian government to go through those details," he said of the news this morning. "But I'm certainly focused on a sporting event that will happen in two days time with the Matildas and I think that the whole of Australia will be cheering them on, with the opportunity that we have of hosting the World Cup here." "The World Cup is the third largest sporting event held in the world, only beaten by the men's football World Cup and the Olympic Games. And we're hosting it, we're hosting the Olympics in south-east Queensland, of course, in 2032. And Australia has a fine record of hosting events."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Anthony Albanese responds to Games cancellation

children.content: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese was a little hesitant to say too much about the Games cancellation, preferring to focus on events that were actually going ahead.
"That's a decision made by the Victorian government. I'll leave the Victorian government to go through those details," he said of the news this morning.

"But I'm certainly focused on a sporting event that will happen in two days time with the Matildas and I think that the whole of Australia will be cheering them on, with the opportunity that we have of hosting the World Cup here."

"The World Cup is the third largest sporting event held in the world, only beaten by the men's football World Cup and the Olympic Games. And we're hosting it, we're hosting the Olympics in south-east Queensland, of course, in 2032.
And Australia has a fine record of hosting events."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The premier has been asked why the Games couldn't have been held in Melbourne, rather than cancelled altogether? He says the government has "looked at every option". "We have looked at every conceivable option. All of them are far in excess of the $2.6 billion that's been budgeted, so all of them represent more cost than there is benefit, and on that basis none of those options stack up and we're not going to be hosting the Games in 2026." He said many of Melbourne's competition-grade facilities were "fairly busy". "So there is a cost so we would not be using them, and there is also the small matter of you could save money by not building villages for instance, but then every hotel room in the city would be pretty much taken up by those who are part of the Games, not those who are coming here to watch the Games. "So again the cost-benefit ratio does not stack up."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: So why not just move the Games to Melbourne?

children.content: The premier has been asked why the Games couldn't have been held in Melbourne, rather than cancelled altogether?
He says the government has "looked at every option".

"We have looked at every conceivable option. All of them are far in excess of the $2.6 billion that's been budgeted, so all of them represent more cost than there is benefit, and on that basis none of those options stack up and we're not going to be hosting the Games in 2026."
He said many of Melbourne's competition-grade facilities were "fairly busy".

"So there is a cost so we would not be using them, and there is also the small matter of you could save money by not building villages for instance, but then every hotel room in the city would be pretty much taken up by those who are part of the Games, not those who are coming here to watch the Games.
"So again the cost-benefit ratio does not stack up."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The government is committed to improving sporting facilities across regional Victoria and says the planned upgrades that were to accompany the Games will still go ahead. That includes upgrading Eureka Stadium in Ballarat to seat 10,000 spectators and upgrades to Bendigo Stadium.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Regional sporting facilities to be upgraded

children.content: The government is committed to improving sporting facilities across regional Victoria and says the planned upgrades that were to accompany the Games will still go ahead.
That includes upgrading Eureka Stadium in Ballarat to seat 10,000 spectators and upgrades to Bendigo Stadium.

image.altText: daniel andrews tours ballarat's eureka stadium at announcement of 2026 commonwealth games

items.synopsis: The Andrews government has scrapped the regional Victorian Commonwealth Games, just 15 months on from announcing it would serve as the 2026 host.

title.children: Commonwealth Games cancelled in regional Victoria as government shrinks from $7b price tag

title.children: Russia's war tactics keep evolving. If Ukraine is to emerge victorious, it needs to be faster

image.altText: A white man with no hair, dressed in a suit, sits behind a microphone with a concerned expression.

image.altText: A mobile phone is held in a person's hand at the ASX in Sydney

items.synopsis: Wall Street gained on optimism about good company profit results and the ASX is lower after a fall in oil prices. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: US stocks rally on company profit hopes, RBA minutes in focus, ASX in the red

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Senate committee into consulting firms is continuing another day of hearings into the big four accounting firms following the PwC tax leaks scandal. EY's Oceania chief executive David Larocca says a workplace review being carried out by former Sex Discrimination commissioner Elizabeth Broderick will be finished by the end of July. The review is investigating bullying, sexual harassment, racism, psychological safety and the impact of work demands at EY. "I expect it to reveal some uncomfortable matters," Mr Larocca told the committee.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: EY workplace review to be finished soon

children.content: The Senate committee into consulting firms is continuing another day of hearings into the big four accounting firms following the PwC tax leaks scandal.
EY's Oceania chief executive David Larocca says a workplace review being carried out by former Sex Discrimination commissioner Elizabeth Broderick will be finished by the end of July.
The review is investigating bullying, sexual harassment, racism, psychological safety and the impact of work demands at EY.
"I expect it
to reveal some uncomfortable matters," Mr Larocca told the committee.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market has opened in the red. Energy stocks are weighing on the market after a fall in oil stocks overnight. The ASX 200 index is down 0.3 per cent to 7,280 with slightly more sectors lower than higher. The best and worst performers are: Block: +3.5% Graincorp: +2.7% NRW: +2.4% Ansell: -13.4% Syrah Resources: -9.6% Metcash: -3.1%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX opens in the red

children.content: The Australian share market has opened in the red.
Energy stocks are weighing on the market after a fall in oil stocks overnight.
The ASX 200 index is down 0.3 per cent to 7,280 with slightly more sectors lower than higher.
The best and worst performers are:
Block: +3.5%
Graincorp: +2.7%
Ansell: -13.4%
Syrah Resources: -9.6%
Metcash: -3.1%

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: ANZ and Roy Morgan say consumer confidence decreased by 0.7 per cent last week to 72.6 as Australians worry about the economy. It was the third fall in consumer confidence in a row with the confidence among the worst levels since the COVID-19 outbreak. Confidence fell in New South Wales and Victoria, but increased in Queensland, South Australia and Western Australia. ANZ says people are worried about high inflation and financial conditions. Confidence in current financial conditions fell by 5.7 points, while confidence that it was a good time to buy a major household item dropped by 0.8 per cent, after a 6.8 per cent fall in the previous week. ANZ senior economist Adelaide Timbrell says confidence among renters was at a record low, while it improved for those paying off their homes. "The confidence level was among the five worst results since the COVID outbreak and has stayed below 80 for 20 straight weeks." "The decline in the latest result was mainly driven by weaker confidence in current financial conditions. " Among the housing cohorts, confidence fell to a record low for those renting. "It improved among those paying off their homes but remained below 70, while it fell for those who own their homes outright."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Consumer confidence falls again

children.content: ANZ and Roy Morgan say consumer confidence decreased by 0.7 per cent last week to 72.6 as Australians worry about the economy.
It was the third fall in consumer confidence in a row with the confidence among the worst levels since the COVID-19 outbreak.
Confidence fell in New South Wales and Victoria, but increased in Queensland, South Australia and Western Australia.
Consumer confidence
(ANZ Roy Morgan)
ANZ says people are worried about high inflation and financial conditions.

Confidence in current financial conditions fell by 5.7 points, while confidence that it was a good time to buy a major household item dropped by 0.8 per cent, after a 6.8 per cent fall in the previous week.
ANZ senior economist Adelaide Timbrell says confidence among renters was at a record low, while it improved for those paying off their homes.
"The confidence level was among the five worst results since the COVID outbreak and has stayed below 80 for 20 straight weeks."
"The decline in the latest result was mainly driven by weaker confidence in current financial conditions.
" Among the housing cohorts, confidence fell to a record low for those renting.
"It improved among those paying off their homes but remained below 70, while it fell for those who own their homes outright."
